prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story: My observation is there exists unequal share of State monies with its residents, before all the Urban residents get defensive please hear me out. Presently no one except Corporations pay State income taxes. No individual pays state taxes. I noticed state funded bicycle paths, road maintenance, defunct Docks, powerful politicians pet projects such as office buildings, state troopers etc, etc. all these fundings and more are not necessary within City limits, I was amazed at how much our state provides city functions in the bigger cities thus growing the state budget, I saw on tv last night how adg&g was showing the little ones how to ice fish, couldn't the parents do that? yes I pay property taxes. But I will guarantee you once our City folk get the full bill with out the State monies we will not be as wasteful, on the office building...rent what space you need and help the office rental marked. In my business I just retired from,I would ask my managers, "how do you stop spending money"?
stories: My point is that the distribution of state funds is uneven, favoring urban residents. I'd like to address this before city residents become defensive. Currently, corporations are the only entities paying state income taxes, while individuals are exempt. I've noticed that state-funded projects, such as bike paths, road maintenance, and extravagant office buildings, might not be necessary within city limits. However, these initiatives still eat into the state's budget, particularly in larger cities. I question whether some programs, like ice fishing lessons, couldn't be managed by parents instead. As a homeowner who pays property taxes, I predict that city dwellers would become more mindful of their expenses if they shouldered the entire financial burden without relying on state funds. This might even help optimize office space rental and reduce waste. In my previous business, I would ask my managers how to curb unnecessary spending, and I foresee applying the same principle to our city's fiscal approach.

Here is the rephrased text:

My observation is that the distribution of state funds is unfairly biased towards urban inhabitants. To head off resentment, I want to discuss this issue openly before city residents become defensive. Currently, businesses are the sole contributors to state income taxes, while individuals enjoy a free pass. I notice that state-funded projects, such as bike paths, highway upkeep, and luxurious office buildings, may not be priorities within city boundaries. Nonetheless, these initiatives continue to drain the state budget, especially in larger metropolitan areas. I wonder if some programs, like offering ice fishing lessons, could be relinquished to parents to handle. As a homeowner paying property taxes, I believe that if city residents were solely responsible for their own financial burdens, without resorting to state assistance, they would become more mindful of their expenses. This, in turn, might help optimize office space and reduce waste. Throughout my past professional endeavors, I've learned the importance of streamlining unnecessary expenses, and I envision adopting a similar philosophy for our city's fiscal planning.
